text:
I used to develop packages in Python using Jupyter notebooks. Now I think it's a terrible idea - but of course it comes down to what workflow works for you.
Generally though, good editors will be more helpful than notebooks: They have linters and spell checkers, better auto-suggestions and file explorers, and more settings

text: I think Pluto.jl is great for exploratory coding and for writing running documentation which are both important parts of package development. However, you can't throw the Pluto.jl files directly into a package, so there needs to be some document generation happening (Pluto.jl file -> `src/*.jl` file). Am currently working on a document generation system that can handle different input and output formats; currently it takes in `.md` , `.ipynb` and literate `.jl` and outputs `.html` docs, but I've thought about using Pluto.jl files as a source from which `src` and `test` directories are generated. Another idea was to write tutorials in Pluto.jl and then on the documentation page provide a one-click launch of a binder kernel running Pluto.jl, so that readers can play around with the code.
